analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper addresses the distributed consensus controller design approaches for one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear multiagents by employing relative state feedback. A new treatment for one-sided Lipschitz nonlinearity is rendered from the consensus control point of view. By employing the quadratic inner-boundedness and the one-sided Lipschitz constraints, a sufficient condition for asymptotic consensus of nonlinear systems under strongly connected communication topologies is provided. Further, a robust consensus protocol design scheme for the nonlinear multiagents is derived by ensuring the L 2 stability of the consensus error system. Furthermore, a novel robust consensus control scheme against amplitude-bounded perturbations is developed that guarantees asymptotic convergence of the consensus error into a compact set. Extensions to the proposed methodologies for the leader-following consensus for a spanning tree communication topology with the leader as the root are addressed. In contrast to the conventional consensus control methodologies, this paper is less conservative and can be applied to a broader class of nonlinear multiagent systems. Moreover, the proposed consensus control approach is less conservative for robustness against disturbances owing to its ability to handle amplitude-bounded disturbances and due to the relaxation of a balanced communication topology. A numerical simulation study is provided for the consensus control of eight mobile agents.

behavior of multiagents by providing suitable feedback control signals and by incorporating communication or network topologies. To address the communication protocols between the multiagents, graph theory has been effectively utilized for the modeling of networks and the derivation of stability conditions via Lyapunov theory.

Some important results on the consensus control of specific classes of linear, nonlinear, and fractional-order multiagents, as seen in [7]- [9], [10], [12], and [13], respectively, have been developed. However, because various communication topologies and multiple nonlinear systems must be considered, the derivation of suitable control protocols is challenging for generalized forms of linear systems and especially challenging for nonlinear systems.

Consensus control strategies for linear multiagents have been the main focus of researchers over the last decade. To synchronize multiple discrete-time single-and doubleintegrator agents, decentralized model predictive control approaches were derived in [14] by incorporating input constraints. In [15], an optimal control approach to optimize a global cost function for a deeper understanding of the stability was investigated for attaining the consensus point of multiagents. The control scheme in [16] employed higher order consensus protocols to provide some necessary and sufficient consensus conditions by characterizing the region of consensus. Distributed adaptive protocols using dynamic output feedback by providing suitable adaptation laws for edge-based and node-based control remedies were explored in [17] for a generalized form of linear multiagents having undirected communication topologies. In [18], the issue of input and communication time delays for the consensus of linear agents subjected to a directed spanning tree during communication was explored, and sufficient conditions for consensus control were developed. Note that most of the abovementioned papers dealt with linear systems; however, a large number of existing systems are encountered by various types of nonlinearities that should be incorporated in consensus protocol design.

As far as nonlinear systems are concerned, consensus control techniques are lacking in the literature, and there is a great demand for the development of consensus protocols for different classes of nonlinear systems. For this reason, several attempts have recently been made to synchronize nonlinear systems by considering various communication topologies. In [19], a consensus protocol was explored based on the Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy model, under an arbitrary communication topology, for robustness against perturbations.
2168-2216 c 2017 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

For uncertain nonlinear mechanical systems, an adaptive leaderless distributed finite-time control strategy under an undirected communication topology was developed in [20]. Fully distributed adaptive synchronization of voltages of inverter-based power micro-grids by the application of neural networks for the compensation of uncertainties was addressed in [21]. Further, in [22], consensus control protocols for the distributed cooperative learning of discrete-time nonlinear multiagents were presented by employing radial basis function neural networks to ensure consensus errors were uniformly ultimately bounded. State feedback consensus control approaches for Lipschitz nonlinear systems with directed communication topologies, incorporating the properties of Lipschitz continuity, were presented in [23] and [24]. Edgebased distributed adaptive protocols for Lipschitz nonlinear systems were employed in [25], and a transformation-oriented consensus control methodology was formulated in [26]. The most recent work on the consensus control of Lipschitz nodes, utilizing state feedback for dealing with switching communication topologies, was provided in [27].

The Lipschitz continuity employed for the nodes in [23]- [27] was conservative; however, an advanced form called the one-sided Lipschitz continuity is now being utilized for the observer and controller designs of nonlinear systems [28]- [31]. This generalized Lipschitz continuity is not only less conservative than the conventional Lipschitz condition but can be used to represent a more general form of nonlinear agents. Some recent results addressed the synchronization and consensus control of one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear systems by incorporating graph theory. A preliminary work on the consensus protocol design using a simple Lyapunov function for one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear systems under the effect of disturbance by employing a robust stability approach is provided in [32]. A leader-following consensus approach using an observer-based control protocol has been studied for the tracking of multiple nonlinear agents satisfying the one-sided Lipschitz [33] and generalized linear incremental [34] conditions. Sufficient conditions for the leaderless synchronization of one-sided Lipschitz agents with linear coupling by adjusting the coupling weight have been addressed in [35]. However, the work on the consensus of one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear agents is still insufficient to address the fundamental issues in [32]- [35] and to synthesize the consensus protocols for nonlinear systems with more general nonlinearities than those found in [23]- [27].

Motivated by the above discussion, this paper aims to fill the research gap on the consensus control of one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear systems under undirected or directed communication topologies. A relative state feedback consensus protocol with coupling weight is proposed for one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear agents by employing the quadratic inner-boundedness and onesided Lipschitz conditions for derivation of the control protocols. The main contribution of this paper is fourfold: First, the dynamics of the nonlinear agents considered in this paper are more general than those in [23]- [27] due to the incorporation of one-sided Lipschitz and quadratic inner-boundedness conditions. In this regard, a new treatment for the more general onesided Lipschitz nonlinearities is explored in this paper from the leaderless consensus control point of view. Second, a sufficient condition for determining the consensus protocol gain and the coupling weight based on the relative state feedback is derived that ensures asymptotic convergence of the consensus error to the origin. Third, two novel robust consensus control criteria against external perturbations are provided by ensuring the L 2 gain reduction between the external disturbances and the consensus error and by guaranteeing asymptotic convergence of the consensus error into a compact set. It is worth noting that the resultant robust consensus treatments are less conservative than the existing approaches (e.g., [23]) in dealing with amplitude-bounded disturbances and the relaxation of balanced communication topologies. Fourth, extensions to the proposed asymptotic and robust consensus protocol design conditions to the leader-following scenario of one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear multiagents are provided.

A similar problem on the consensus approach of onesided Lipschitz nonlinear agents was considered in [32] by ignoring the input matrix. Compared to this approach, this paper considers a more complicated control situation by considering the input matrix, deriving the proposed synchronization criteria by employing a more general Lyapunov function, and taking amplitude-bounded disturbances as well as energy-bounded disturbances into account to achieve the robust consensus. In contrast to the leader-following control schemes found in [33] and [34], this paper explores the different control problem of the leaderless consensus protocol synthesis of nonlinear multiagents. It is worth noting that the error stability analysis of leaderless consensus control is more difficult than that of leader-following consensus control. In the leader-following case, the consensus errors are defined between the states of leaders and all other agents (e.g., z i = x ix 1 ), while in the leaderless case, the synchronization errors are constructed by using the states of all the agents (e.g., e i = x i -N j=1 r j x j ). Therefore, a more complex stability analysis is required to design a consensus protocol. The proposed methodology differs from the leaderless synchronization approach of coupled nonlinear systems [35], when applied to consensus control, in several aspects due to its consideration of the input matrix, state feedback gain, and freedom in choice adjacency matrix entries (other than zero or one). Moreover, the robustness of the consensus protocol has been addressed with respect to the disturbances in comparison to the conventional approaches [33]- [35]. Compared to our recent work on the consensus of Lipschitz systems in [36], the proposed consensus control differs in three aspects. First, a more practical directed communication topology, rather than the undirected topology, is incorporated in this paper. Second, the present consensus control is applicable to a more general class of nonlinear system due to generalization of the one-sided Lipschitz continuity. Last, robustness against amplitude-bounded perturbations is taken into account in this paper, unlike in [36], to consider a more realistic control environment. A simulation example of a network of eight mobile agents in the absence and presence of external perturbations is provided to demonstrate the strength of the proposed methods.

This paper is organized as follows. Section II details the system description. The proposed consensus protocol design conditions for the leaderless and leader-following scenarios are given in Sections III and IV, respectively. Simulation results for a network of eight moving systems are provided in Section V, and the conclusions are drawn in Section VI.

Standard notation is employed in this paper. For X ∈ R n×n , X > 0 represents a symmetric positive-definite matrix X, while X ≥ 0 is used for a symmetric semi-positive-definite matrix X. diag(M 1 , . . . , M N ) is employed to denote a block diagonal matrix with diagonal entries M i . The Kronecker product of matrices X and Y is given by X ⊗ Y. For a vector x,
x and x 2 symbolize the standard Euclidean and L 2 norms, respectively. The L 2 gain from a vector d(t) to another vector e(t) is defined by sup d 2 =0 ( e(t) 2 / d(t) 2 ).

div.head: II. SYSTEM DESCRIPTION
div.p: Consider N identical systems, called agents, given by
div.formula: dx i dt = Ax i + f (t, x i ) + Bu i + d i y i (t) = Cx i ∀i = 1, 2, . . . , N(1)
div.p: where The interaction between N connected multiagent systems can be denoted using directed graphs. A weighted directed graph is represented by = ( , ), where the set of vertices and set of edges between two distinct vertices are represented by = {1, 2, . . . , N} and ⊂ × , respectively. A path between nodes i and j in graph is defined as a sequence of edges (i, r) ∈ , where r = 1, 2, . . . , j are distinct vertices. In a weighted undirected graph, a set of edges is an unordered pair of vertices, which implies that an edge (i, j) ∈ shows that agent i can get relative state information from its neighboring agent j and vice versa. A graph topology is said to be connected if there exists a path from any one vertex to any other vertex. A graph is said to be strongly connected if there exists a directed path from any one vertex to any other vertex. A graph has a spanning tree if it is strongly connected, but the converse may not be true. The Laplacian matrix of is represented by
div.formula: x i ∈ n , u i ∈ m ,
= [l ij ] ∈ N×N , whereas the weighted connectivity matrix of a graph is represented by = [a ij ] ∈ N×N .
div.p: The left eigenvector of the Laplacian matrix associated with the zero eigenvalue is denoted by
The function f (t, x i ) validates the one-sided Lipschitz condition and quadratic inner-boundedness constraint, given by
div.formula: f (t, x a ) -f (t, x b ), x a -x b ≤ η x a -x b 2 (2) ( f (t, x a ) -f (t, x b )) T ( f (t, x a ) -f (t, x b )) ≤ δ x a -x b 2 + σ x a -x b , f (t, x a ) -f (t, x b ) (3)
div.p: for scalars η, δ, and σ and vectors x a , x b ∈ n . Assumption 1: The communication topology among the nonlinear agents of (1) can be represented by a strongly connected graph .
Assumption 2: The function f (t, x i ) in (1) satisfies the conditions defined in (2) and (3).

Remark 1: This paper considers the consensus control of the one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear agents in (1) validating the conditions in ( 2) and (3). It should be noted that leaderless consensus protocol design for one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear systems (1) satisfying ( 2)-( 3) under a communication topology has been neglected in previous studies. Treatment of the synchronization error for the case of leaderless consensus control is more challenging than it is for the leader-following consensus control approaches in [33] and [34].

Remark 2: Assumption 1 considers the communication topology between the nonlinear agents as strongly connected. Note that an undirected graph can be represented by a directed graph, and a connected undirected graph is representable via a strongly connected directed graph. Given that the leaderless consensus of one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear agents is neglected in the literature, the approach presented in this paper is aimed at being applicable to both types of communication topologies, namely, connected undirected and strongly connected directed topologies. This is because the proposed consensus control schemes are derived based on the generalized algebraic connectivity of a graph rather than conventional algebraic connectivity. Utilization of the proposed methodology for undirected and directed communication topologies can support its effectiveness for a broader range of communication scenarios between agents.
The proposed control protocol for the ith agent is given as
div.formula: u i = cF N j=1 a ij x i -x j , ∀i = 1, 2, . . . , N(4)
div.p: where c ∈ is the coupling weight and F ∈ m×n is the gain matrix for the protocol. Substituting the consensus protocol (4) into the nonlinear multiagents in (1) reveals
div.formula: dx i dt = Ax i + f (t, x i ) + BcF N j=1 a ij x i -x j + d i y i (t) = Cx i , ∀i = 1, 2, . . . , N(5)
div.p: which can be written as
div.formula: dx dt = I N ⊗ A + c ⊗ BF x + (t, x) + d i (6) ∀i = 1, 2, . . . , N, by substituting x = x T 1 x T 2 . . . x T N T (7
) (t, x) = f T (t, x 1 ) f T (t, x 2 ) . . . f T (t, x N ) T . (8
div.p: In the next section, the leaderless consensus control of nonlinear multiagents will be considered.

div.head: III. CONSENSUS PROTOCOL SYNTHESIS
div.p: The main objective of this paper is to compute the coupling weight c and the protocol gain F for the nonlinear multiagent systems in (1) validating ( 2), (3) under a strongly connected communication topology represented by a graph . We define the consensus (or synchronization) error as

Note that N j=1 r j = 1 and r j > 0. By taking e i = 0, we obtain x 1 = x 2 = . . . = x N via solving N linear equations. Similarly, if x 1 = x 2 = . . . = x N , e i = 0 can be verified from (9). From this discussion, we can conclude that e i = 0 if and only if x 1 = x 2 = . . . = x N . Employing ( 6) and ( 9), the synchronization error system is obtained as
div.formula: de i dt = Ae i + f (t, x i ) - N j=1 r j f t, x j + c N j=1 ij BFe j + 1 N N j=1 d i -d j (10
div.p: ∀i = 1, 2, . . . , N. The asymptotic and robust consensus protocol design conditions are provided in the next sections.

div.head: A. Asymptotic Consensus Protocol
div.p: Now, we provide a consensus protocol synthesis condition by taking d i = 0 in the following theorem.

Theorem 1: Consider the nonlinear multiagents in (1) satisfying d i = 0 and Assumptions 1 and 2. Suppose that there exist a symmetric matrix Q ∈ n×n and a scalar λ for any given positive scalars ε 1 and ε 2 such that the linear matrix inequalities (LMIs)

are satisfied. Then, there exists a control protocol (4) such that the nonlinear agents in (1) achieve consensus as t → ∞ and the consensus error e i , for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N, converges to the origin asymptotically. The coupling weight and the controller gain matrix can be determined by c ≥ λ/α( ) and F = -0.5B T Q -1 , respectively, where α( ) represents the generalized algebraic connectivity of the graph . Proof: Consider the following Lyapunov function:
div.formula: V(t, e i ) = N i=1 r i e T i Pe i , P = P T > 0. (13
div.p: Employing the time-derivative operator and using (10), we obtain
div.formula: V(t, e i ) = 2 N i=1 r i e T i P ⎛ ⎝ Ae i + f (t, x i ) - N j=1 r j f t, x j + c N j=1 ij BFe j + 1 N N j=1 d i -d j ⎞ ⎠ . (14
div.p: By noting
div.formula: N i=1 r i e T i P ⎛ ⎝ f t, xj - N j=1 r j f t, x j ⎞ ⎠ = 0 (15)
div.p: and by substituting
div.formula: xj = N j=1 r j x j . (16
div.p: Equation ( 14) is further simplified as
div.formula: V(t, e i ) = 2 N i=1 r i e T i P ⎛ ⎝ Ae i + c N j=1 ij BFe j + 1 N N j=1 d i -d j ⎞ ⎠ + 2 N i=1 r i e T i P f (t, x i ) -f t, xj . (17
div.p: The one-sided Lipschitz condition in (2) can be written as
div.formula: ε 1 ηe T i e i -ε 1 e T i f (t, x i ) -f t, xj ≥ 0 (18) ∀i = 1, 2, • • • , N, where ε 1 > 0.
div.p: From the quadratic innerboundedness condition, we have
div.formula: -ε 2 f (t, x i ) -f t, xj T f (t, x i ) -f t, xj + ε 2 δe T i e i + ε 2 σ e T i f (t, x i ) -f t, xj ≥ 0, ∀i = 1, 2, . . . , N(19)
div.p: for a positive scalar ε 2 Using ( 17)-( 19), the upper bound on the derivative of the Lyapunov function becomes
div.formula: V(t, e i ) ≤ 2 N i=1 r i e T i P ⎛ ⎝ Ae i + c N j=1 ij BFe j + 1 N N j=1 d i -d j ⎞ ⎠ + 2 N i=1 r i e T i P f (t, x i ) -f t, xj -ε 1 N i=1 r i e T i f (t, x i ) -f t, xj + ε 1 η N i=1 r i e T i e i -ε 2 N i=1 r i f (t, x i ) -f t, xj T f (t, x i ) -f t, xj + ε 2 δ N i=1 r i e T i e i + ε 2 σ N i=1 r i e T i f (t, x i ) -f t, xj . (20
div.p: Employing Finsler's lemma, using F = -0.5B T P, and substituting R = diag(r 1 , r 2 , . . . , r N ), we have
div.formula: V(t, e i ) ≤ ξ T (t) R ⊗ A T P + PA + ε 1 ηI + ε 2 δI ξ(t) -ξ T (t) 0.5c R + T R ⊗ PBB T P ξ(t) + ξ T (t)R ⊗ Pρ(t) + 2ξ T (t)R ⊗ P t, x i , xj -ξ T (t)R ⊗ ε 1 I t, x i , xj + ξ T (t)R ⊗ ε 2 σ I × t, x i , xj -T t, x i , xj R ⊗ ε 2 σ I t, x i , xj di = 1 N N j=1 d i -d j , ∀i = 1, 2, . . . , N ξ T (t) = e T 1 e T 2 . . . e T n , ρ T (t) = dT 1 dT 2 . . . dT n T (t, x i , xj ) = f (t, x 1 ) -f t, xj T f (t, x 2 ) -f t, xj T . . . f (t, x n ) -f t, xj T . (21) Noting -ξ T (t)c R + T R ⊗ I ξ(t) ≤ -2α cξ T (t)R ⊗ Iξ(t) (22
div.p: it follows from ( 21) and ( 22) that:
div.formula: V(t, e i ) ≤ ξ T (t)R ⊗ A T P + PA + ε 1 ηI + ε 2 δI ξ(t) -ξ T (t)cα PBB T Pξ(t) + ξ T (t)R ⊗ Pρ(t) + 2ξ T (t)R ⊗ P t, x i , xj -ξ T (t)R ⊗ ε 1 I × t, x i , xj + ξ T (t)R ⊗ ε 2 σ I t, x i , xj -T t, x i , xj R ⊗ ε 2 I t, x i , xj(23)

div.p: For asymptotic convergence of ξ(t) [that is e i (t)] to the origin, we require
By expanding the Kroncker product, exchanging the rows and columns and rewriting in a compact form, it can be validated that the inequality ( 27) is equivalent to
As R > 0, the condition in (28) holds if and only if
By application of congruence transformation using diag(P -1 , I, I) and substituting Q = P -1 reveal
div.formula: QA T + AQ + (ε 1 η + ε 2 δ)Q 2 -λBB T I -0.5ε 1 Q + 0.5ε 2 σ Q * -ε 2 I < 0. (30
div.p: Employing ε 1 η + ε 1 δ ≤ |ε 1 η + ε 1 δ| and applying the Schur complement reveals (12), which completes the proof.

Remark 3: In Theorem 1, a schema for dealing with the one-sided Lipschitz functions for the consensus control has been provided. From the Lipschitz counterpart, utilization of the one-sided Lipschitz inequality and the quadratic inner-boundedness constraint in (3) and ( 4) is tricky. In the works [23], [25], and [27], the terms containing f (t, x i )f (t, xj ) are eliminated while deriving the upper bound on derivative of the Lyapunov function. However, in the present case, the terms containing f (t, x i )f (t, xj ) in ( 20) cannot be replaced with the consensus error terms; consequently, a new treatment of the nonlinearities satisfying (2), (3) has been provided in the proof of Theorem 1 by defining a nonlinear vector-function (t, x i , xj ) for treating the terms f (t, x i )f (t, xj ). The proposed LMI-based consensus protocol design approach in Theorem 1 is less conservative than the existing methods in [32] and [33]. For instance, the consensus control approach in [33] fails for the negative values of ε 1 η+ε 2 δ compared with the present control scheme. Additionally, a more general Lyapunov function is employed in this paper in contrast to [32]. The study of [32] employs a trivial diagonal Lyapunov function for the consensus control with P = I.

Remark 4: The error term in (9) has variables r j for j = 1, . . . , N, which constitute the matrix R = diag(r 1 , r 2 , . . . , r N ). Elimination of R is required: 1) to solve the consensus protocol design conditions through convex routines and 2) to reduce the size of the matrix in (28) for the reduction of computations to determine the consensus protocol gain. The proposed consensus protocol design condition in Theorem 1 for one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear agents is derived through a complicated elimination of R.

Remark 5: Compared with the results in [23]- [27], the proposed methodology in Theorem 1 can be employed to design a consensus protocol for a broader class of nonlinear systems. The proposed methodology can be applied to nonlinear systems with comparably large Lipschitz constants, because the one-sided Lipschitz inequality constant (which can be zero or even negative) can be either smaller or equal to the corresponding Lipschitz condition constant for a nonlinear function. Moreover, the conditions ( 2) and (3) can represent a broader class of nonlinearities than those employed in [23]- [27]. Note that these two conditions in (2) and (3) are a superset of the conventional Lipschitz condition applied in [23]- [27] and can be used to design less conservative control systems for nonlinear systems, as seen in [28]- [31]. In contrast to the synchronization investigation study [35], the proposed consensus control methodology employs an input matrix B and is based on finding a proper feedback gain matrix F. Therefore, it can be applied to the consensus control problem upon failure of the abovementioned synchronization study.

div.head: B. Robust Consensus Protocol
div.p: Now, we provide a sufficient condition for the synthesis of the robust consensus protocol (4) for one-sided Lipschitz systems (1) against external perturbations.

Theorem 2: Consider the nonlinear multiagents in (1) satisfying Assumptions 1 and 2. Suppose that there exist a symmetric matrix Q ∈ n×n and scalars λ and γ for any given positive scalars ε 1 and ε 2 such that the LMIs

are satisfied. Then, there exists a control protocol (4) such that the consensus error e i for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N converges to the origin asymptotically, if d i = 0 for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N, and the L 2 gain from ρ(t) to ξ(t) remains less than γ , if d i = 0 for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N. The coupling weight and the controller gain matrix can be determined by c ≥ λ/α( ) and F = -0.5B T Q -1 , respectively. Proof: Let us define
div.formula: J(t, e i , d i ) = V(t, e i ) + γ -1 N i=1 r i e T i e i -γ N i=1 r i dT i di(33)
div.p: which further entails
div.formula: J(t, e i , d i ) = V(t, e i ) + γ -1 ξ T (t)R ⊗ Iξ(t) -γρ T (t)R ⊗ Iρ(t). (34
div.p: Considering the inequality J(t, e i , d i ) < 0 and integrating (34) from the time t = 0 to t → ∞, we have 2 2 < 0 under zero initial conditions, because R is a positive-definite diagonal matrix. Given that V(t, e i ) > 0, the inequality given by the relation
div.formula: V(∞, e i ) + γ -1 √ R ⊗ Iξ(t) 2 2 -γ √ R ⊗ Iρ(t)
V(∞, e i ) + γ -1 √ R ⊗ Iξ(t) 2 2 -γ √ R ⊗ Iρ(t) 2 2 < 0 implies √ R⊗Iξ(t) 2 2 < γ 2 √ R⊗Iρ(t) 2 2 .
div.p: It further entails ξ(t) 2 < γ ρ(t) 2 by taking the square root and eliminating the common positive-definite factor √ R. As a result, the L 2 gain between ρ(t) and ξ(t) is bounded by γ . Using ( 23) and ( 34) yields
div.formula: J(t) ≤ ξ T (t)R ⊗ A T P + PA + ε 1 ηI + ε 2 δI ξ(t) -ξ T (t)R ⊗ cα PBB T Pξ(t) + ξ T (t)R ⊗ Pρ(t) + 2ξ T (t)R ⊗ P t, x i , xj -ξ T (t)R ⊗ ε 1 I t, x i , xj + ξ T (t)R ⊗ ε 2 σ I t, x i , xj -T t, x i , xj R ⊗ ε 2 I × t, x i , xj + γ -1 ξ T (t)R ⊗ Iξ(t) -γρ T (t)R ⊗ Iρ(t). (35
Defining ϒ T 2 = ϒ T 1 ρ T (t) , (35) produces J(t, e i , d i ) ≤ ϒ T 2 ⎡ ⎣ R ⊗ 1 + γ -1 I R ⊗ 2 R ⊗ P * -2R ⊗ ε 2 I R⊗ 0 * * -R ⊗ γ I ⎤ ⎦ ϒ 2 . (36
div.p: To ensure J(t, e i , d i ) < 0, we require
which is equivalent to
by changing rows and columns. To attain (38), we have to ensure the following inequality (by application of the Schur complement):
which, by pre-and post-multiplication using diag(P -1 , I, I),
div.formula: setting Q = P -1 , incorporating 2ε 1 η + 2ε 1 δ ≤ |2(ε 1 η + ε 1 δ)|,
div.p: and employing the Schur complement, implies (32). Remark 6: Theorem 2 provides a sufficient condition for the consensus protocol design by ensuring the bounded L 2 gain from ρ(t) to ξ(t). The derived condition can be applied to reach a robust consensus against perturbations in comparison to Theorem 1 and the approaches in [33]- [35]. Work on robust distributed consensus approach design for nonlinear agents is lacking in the literature, while the disturbances can cause performance degradation and drift of the consensus error to infinity if not considered [37]- [39]. Therefore, the condition in Theorem 2 can be utilized to find a robust coupling weight as well as robust protocol gain to attenuate the disturbance effects at the consensus error.

The following corollary is obtained under ε 1 = 0, ε 2 = 1/2, σ = 0, and μ = √ δ from Theorem 2. Corollary 1: Consider the nonlinear multiagents in (1) satisfying Assumption 1 and the Lipschitz condition f (t, x a )f (t, x b ) ≤ μ x ax b , for Lipschitz constant μ and vectors x a , x b ∈ n . Suppose that there exist a symmetric matrix Q ∈ n×n and scalars λ and γ such that the LMIs (31) and

are satisfied. Then, there exists a control protocol (4) such that the consensus error e i for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N converges to the origin asymptotically, if d i = 0 for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N, and the L 2 gain from ρ(t) to ξ(t) remains less than γ , if d i = 0 for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N. The coupling weight and the controller gain matrix can be determined by c ≥ λ/α( ) and F = -0.5B T Q -1 , respectively. Proof: For σ = 0 and μ = √ δ, the quadratic innerboundedness condition in (3) is equivalent to f (t, x a )f (t, x b ) ≤ μ x ax b . Substituting the condition ε 1 = 0, ε 2 = 1/2, σ = 0, and μ = √ δ into (32) reveals (40), which completes the proof.

Remark 7: In [23], a condition for robust consensus protocol against disturbances for Lipschitz nonlinear agents was designed by employing a Lyapunov function like V(t, e i ) = N i=1 e T i Pe i , rather than ( 13), and by taking r i = 1, for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N, (i.e., R = I) into (33). This substitution limits the applicability of the approach presented in [23] to the strongly connected and balanced communication topologies. In contrast, the present approach in Corollary 1 (see also [40] for synchronization of the coupled systems network case) derived by substituting ε 1 = 0, ε 2 = 1, σ = 0, and μ = √ δ in Theorem 2 is less conservative, because the communication topology is not restricted to balanced topologies. Note that the results in Theorem 2 and Corollary 1 are obtained via a special treatment of the L 2 gain reduction by means of a more broad-spectrum inequality J(t, e i , d i ) < 0 and Lyapunov function ( 13) containing scalars r i and through elimination of the matrix R from both the resultant design inequalities (32) and ( 40) and the L 2 gain relation ξ(t) 2 / ρ(t) 2 < γ .

In many practical cases, bounds on amplitudes of disturbances are somehow known, while the L 2 norm of disturbances may not be bounded. For instance, if the disturbances are persistent, ρ(t) 2 may approach infinity, and the criteria proposed in Theorem 2 and Corollary 1 are inapplicable. Therefore, we provide a consensus controller synthesis condition to deal with amplitude-bounded disturbances and perturbations.

Theorem 3: Consider the nonlinear multiagents in (1) satisfying Assumptions 1 and 2. Suppose that there exist a symmetric matrix Q ∈ n×n and scalars λ and ζ for any given positive scalars ε 1 and ε 2 such that the LMIs

are satisfied. Then, there exists a control protocol ( 4) such that the consensus error e i for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N converges to a compact set N i=1 r i e T i Q -1 e i ≤ ζ ϑ if the disturbances d i for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N acting on the agents have bounded amplitudes, where ϑ is a scalar satisfying ρ T (t)R ⊗ Iρ(t) ≤ ϑ. The coupling weight and the controller gain matrix can be determined by c ≥ λ/α( ) and F = -0.5B T Q -1 , respectively.
Proof: Consider the inequality
div.formula: V(t, e i ) + V(t, e i ) -ζ N i=1 r i dT i di < 0, ζ > 0. (43
div.p: It further implies
div.formula: V(t, e i ) + V(t, e i ) -ζρ T (t)R ⊗ Iρ(t) < 0. (44
div.p: The inequality (44) implies that V(t, e i ) < 0 if V(t, e i ) ≥ ζρ T (t)R ⊗ Iρ(t). That is, the consensus error is asymptotically stable outside the region V(t, e i ) = ζρ T (t)R ⊗ Iρ(t).

Given that the disturbances have bounded amplitudes, we have ρ T (t)R ⊗ Iρ(t) ≤ ϑ for a scalar ϑ. Hence, the consensus error converges to the compact set V(t, e i ) ≤ ζ ϑ, which further implies the region (ζ ϑ) -1 N i=1 r i e T i Q -1 e i ≤ 1 for Q = P -1 and using (13). The condition in ( 42) can be derived from (44) using steps similar to those used in the proof of Theorem 2.

Remark 8: The conventional approaches to the consensus control of linear or nonlinear systems, such as [23] and [32], considered L 2 norm-bounded disturbances, as in Theorem 2 and Corollary 1. In contrast, the approach provided in Theorem 3 is based on amplitude-bounded disturbances, which is more practical in nature, because the disturbances acting on the multiagent systems are always bounded. Theorem 3 provides a novel consensus control criterion to ensure asymptotic convergence of the consensus error into a compact set
div.formula: N i=1 r i e T i Q -1 e i ≤ ζ ϑ.
div.p: The size of the compact set for attaining robustness against disturbances can be reduced by minimizing the scalar ζ and the largest eigenvalue of Q. Further, the condition in Theorem 3 can be more enlightening than that in Theorem 2, as it directly provides the information on the bound on the amplitude of the consensus error. Also note that novel conditions for the consensus of the Lipschitz agents under disturbances with bounded amplitudes for strongly connected and strongly connected balanced communication topologies can be derived from Theorem 3.

div.head: IV. EXTENSION TO LEADER-FOLLOWING CONSENSUS
div.p: The previous section considered leaderless consensus control for strongly connected nonlinear multiagent systems. In many consensus applications, such as the movement of air vehicles, there is a leader with multiple following agents, and a feedback controller is needed for consensus between the followers and the leader. In the leader-following consensus, it may not be possible for all the agents to access the information of the leader; therefore, the information of the other agents plays an important role in the synchronization. The first agent in (1) for i = 1 is assumed to be the leader. Further, the leader node is assumed to be a root; therefore, it can only transmit information and no information from the followers is applied for the consensus control, leading to u 1 = 0. The leader dynamics can be written as
div.formula: dx 1 dt = Ax 1 + f (t, x 1 ) + d 1 y 1 (t) = Cx 1 .(45)
div.p: The consensus protocol for the remaining N -1 agents is given by
div.formula: u i = cF N j=1 a ij x i -x j , ∀i = 2, . . . , N. (46
div.p: Assumption 3: The communication topology has a spanning tree with a leader as a root.
The Laplacian matrix can be partitioned as
where [23] and [41]. Let the smallest eigenvalue of Y be υ. Defining the consensus tracking error as z i = x i -x 1 for all i = 2, . . . , N, the closed-loop system using (1) and (46) becomes
div.formula: ∈ (N-1)×1 and ∈ (N-1)×(N-1) . Assigning [p 2 , . . . , p N ] T = -1 p min = min(p 2 , . . . , p N ), we have U = diag(p -1 2 , . . . , p -1 N ) > 0 and Y = 0.5(U + T U) > 0, as seen in
dz i dt = Az i + f (t, x i ) -f (t, x 1 ) + cF N j=1 a ij z i -z j + di (48) ∀i = 2, . . . , N, where di = d i -d 1 .
div.p: In the following, we extend the results of Theorems 1 and 2 to the case of leader-following consensus control.

Theorem 4: Consider the nonlinear multiagents in (1) satisfying di = 0, for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N, and Assumptions 2 and 3. Suppose that there exist a symmetric matrix W ∈ n×n and IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SYSTEMS, MAN, AND CYBERNETICS: SYSTEMS a scalar χ for any given positive scalars ε 1 and ε 2 such that the LMIs

are satisfied. Then, there exists a control protocol (46) such that the nonlinear agents in (1) achieve consensus as t → ∞, and the consensus error z i , for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N, converges to the origin asymptotically. The coupling weight and the controller gain matrix can be determined by c ≥ χυ -1 p -1 min and F = -0.5B T W -1 , respectively.
Proof: Consider a Lyapunov function
div.formula: Ṽ(t, z i ) = N i=2 p -1 i z T i W -1 z i . (51
div.p: The time derivative of (51) along (48) becomes
div.formula: V(t, z i ) = 2 N i=2 p -1 i z T i W -1 ⎛ ⎝ Az i + c N j=1 ij BFz j + di ⎞ ⎠ + 2 N i=1 p -1 i z T i W -1 (f (t, x i ) -f (t, x 1 )).(52)
div.p: Incorporating ( 2) and (3), using Finsler's lemma with F = -0.5B T W -1 , and substituting U = diag(p -1 2 , . . . , p -1 N ) > 0 and Y = 0.5(U + T U) > 0, we have
div.formula: V(t, z i ) ≤ ξ T (t) U ⊗ A T W -1 + W -1 A + ε 1 ηI + ε 2 δI ξ(t) -ξ T (t)cY ⊗ W -1 BB T W -1 ξ(t) + ξ T (t)U ⊗ W -1 ρ(t) + 2 ξ T (t)U ⊗ W -1 ˜ (t, x i , x 1 ) -ξ T (t)U ⊗ ε 1 I × ˜ (t, x i , x 1 ) + ξ T (t)U ⊗ ε 2 σ I ˜ (t, x i , x 1 ) -˜ T (t, x i , x 1 )U ⊗ ε 2 σ I ˜ (t, x i , x 1 ) ξ T (t) = z T 2 • • • z T n , ρT (t) = dT 2 • • • dT n ˜ T (t, x i , x 1 ) = ( f (t, x 2 ) -f (t, x 1 )) T • • • ( f (t, x N ) -f (t, x 1 )) T . (53
div.p: The inequality cY ≥ χ U is valid if c ≥ χυ -1 p -1 min . Incorporating cY ≥ χ U and di = 0 and following the same steps as in the proof of Theorem 1, we obtain the constraint (50) in Theorem 4.
The robust leader-following consensus protocol design condition for nonlinear systems is provided in Theorem 5.

Theorem 5: Consider the nonlinear multiagents in (1) satisfying Assumptions 2 and 3. Suppose that there exist a symmetric matrix W ∈ n×n and scalars η and γ for any given positive scalars ε 1 and ε 2 such that the LMIs

are satisfied. Then, there exists a control protocol (46) such that the consensus error z i for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N converges to the origin asymptotically, if di = 0 for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N, and the L 2 gain from ρ(t) to ξ(t) remains less than γ , if di = 0 for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N. The coupling weight and the controller gain matrix can be determined by c ≥ χυ -1 p -1 min and F = -0.5B T W -1 , respectively. Proof: By defining
div.formula: J t, z i , di = V(t, z i ) + γ -1 N i=2 p -1 i z T i z i -γ N i=2 p -1 i dT i di = ˙V(t, z i ) + γ -1 ξ T (t)U ⊗ I ξ(t) -γ ρT (t)U ⊗ I ρ(t)(56)
div.p: incorporating (48), using cY ≥ χ U, and employing the same steps as in the proof of Theorem 2, we obtain the inequalities in Theorem 5, which completes the proof. For Lipschitz nonlinear multiagent systems, Theorem 5 reduces to the following corollary by the application of ε 1 = 0, ε 2 = 1/2, σ = 0, and μ = √ δ in an analogous way as in the proof of Corollary 1.

Corollary 2: Consider the nonlinear multiagents in (1) satisfying Assumption 3 and the Lipschitz condition f (t, x a )f (t, x b ) ≤ μ x ax b , for Lipschitz constant μ and vectors x a , x b ∈ n . Suppose that there exist a symmetric matrix W ∈ n×n and scalars η and γ such that the LMIs (54) and

are satisfied. Then, there exists a control protocol (46) such that the consensus error z i for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N converges to the origin asymptotically, if di = 0 for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N, and the L 2 gain from ρ(t) to ξ(t) remains less than γ , if di = 0 for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N. The coupling weight and the controller gain matrix can be determined by c ≥ χυ -1 p -1 min and F = -0.5B T W -1 , respectively. Remark 9: Theorem 4 provides a sufficient condition for the leader-following consensus control of one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear systems with a spanning tree containing the leader as a root. Unlike that in Theorem 1, the proposed consensus protocol in Theorem 4 can be employed to reach a consensus between the nonlinear agents by incorporating the leader tracking constraint. Similarly, the condition in Theorem 5 can be applied for the robust leader-following consensus control of nonlinear multiagent systems, unlike that in Theorem 2. The novel results in Corollary 2 are a specific case of Theorem 5 for Lipschitz nonlinear systems and can be applied to leader-following scenarios under Assumption 3 without any requirement of a balanced communication topology.

Remark 10: Leader-following consensus control, ensuring uniformly ultimately bounded stability as in [42], of nonlinear multiagents has been neglected in amplitude-bounded disturbance cases (see [43]). Leader-following consensus control protocol design conditions for Lipschitz and one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear multiagent systems for attaining convergence of the consensus error into a small compact set can be derived by employing the tactics used for the derivation of Theorems 3 and 5. These solutions are now trivial; therefore, they are left for the reader.

The proposed synchronization methodologies for the onesided Lipschitz agents are derived by incorporating the effects of disturbances under fixed directed communication topologies. In many practical situations, the communication topologies do not remain fixed, because switching between communication links can occur due to the timevarying nature of communication topologies. In such cases, adaptive consensus control methodologies, like the leaderfollowing consensus approaches of [44] and [45], can be employed to deal with the switching topologies. Further, lags at the input and output as in [46] can also be incorporated while designing the consensus protocols. In future, the adaptive consensus of delayed one-sided Lipschitz agents with switching topologies and fully distributed consensus protocol can be studied.

div.head: V. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: Consider the eight nonlinear multiagents, representing the dynamics of mobile agents in Cartesian coordinates (see [28]- [30]), described by

It has been verified that f (t, x i ) is a one-sided Lipschitz nonlinearity with η = 0, and there are various choices of σ and δ depending upon the region of operation. In this paper, we select σ = -100 and δ = -99 based on the observations in [28]- [30]. Now, we divide our simulation study into two parts based on the absence and presence of disturbances.

div.head: A. Case I: Asymptotic Consensus Control
div.p: Let us consider d i = 0. We fix ε 1 = ε 2 = 0.05 for this paper. The initial conditions are taken to be
(61) By solving the constraints in Theorem 1, we obtain

div.head: B. Case II: Robust Consensus Control
div.p: Now, the consensus control problem for nonlinear multiagents of (1) subjected to external disturbances is considered. Let us assume that the external disturbances on the multiagents are given by for the L 2 gain γ = 0.12 to achieve a robust consensus. The protocol gain matrix is obtained as F = -1.022 -10.22 .

The robust coupling weight is selected as c = 18.013 under the condition c ≥ λ/α( ). closed-loop state trajectories in the presence of external disturbances by the application of the proposed robust consensus protocol are shown in Figs. 4 and 5 for x i1 and x i2 for all i = 1, . . . , 8. The initial conditions are taken to be the same as (61). It can be observed that the states x i1 for i = 1, . . . , 8 achieve a common time profile in a finite amount of time, as demonstrated by Fig. 4. Similarly, the convergence of the states x i2 for i = 1, . . . , 8 is also robust against disturbances to attain coherent behavior. Hence, the external disturbances are efficiently rejected by the application of the proposed consensus protocol to achieve identical behavior of the one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear multiagents. In future, the proposed method can be worked out for the formation control of one-sided Lipschitz agents, and the communication topology can be treated as switching.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: This paper considered the consensus control of one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear agents by the application of a relative state feedback protocol. Both leaderless and leader-following consensus protocol synthesis conditions ensuring asymptotic stability of the consensus error system were derived for strongly connected and spanning tree communication topologies, respectively. Further, external perturbations were incorporated for formulating the robust consensus control synthesis strategies by employing the L 2 stability theory. Novel results on the robust consensus of Lipschitz systems, without any requirement of balanced communication topology, were derived from the proposed methodology for one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear systems. Furthermore, robust consensus controller synthesis for one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear systems was addressed under amplitude-bounded perturbations for asymptotic stability of the consensus error outside a compact region. Compared with the existing methods, the resultant consensus protocols are less conservative and can be applied to a broader class of nonlinear systems. In addition, the resultant approaches are more efficient for handling disturbances, because of the relaxation of balanced communication topologies and the incorporation of more realistic disturbances. A numerical example was provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed consensus control methodologies in the absence and presence of external disturbances. Feedback of relative output and switching of the communication topologies for the consensus protocol design of one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear multiagent systems under disturbances and delays can be considered in future.

We can see that all the respective state trajectories of the agents are achieving consensus by utilizing the proposed protocol. IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SYSTEMS, MAN, AND CYBERNETICS: SYSTEMS

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
div.p: The authors would like to thank to Prof. S. S. Ge, Director of the Social Robotics Laboratory, Interactive Digital Media Institute, National University of Singapore, for his valuable comments on the initial version of this paper.
